criterion: Provides an overly simplistic or incomplete explanation of the recovery process for a mild ankle sprain.
States that rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) are the only steps to take for a mild ankle sprain, without mentioning the importance of seeking medical attention if symptoms worsen.
Incorrectly advises using heat to treat a mild ankle sprain.
Asks the user to describe their ankle sprain in detail to better understand their situation.
Uses technical medical jargon or overly complex language to explain the recovery process.
Incorrectly advises using painkillers to treat a mild ankle sprain.
Provides a clear and concise explanation of the recovery process for a mild ankle sprain, including the importance of seeking medical attention if symptoms worsen.
States that compression bandages are only necessary for severe ankle sprains, when in fact they can be helpful for all levels of ankle sprains.
Asks the user to clarify any specific concerns or questions they have about the recovery process.
Incorrectly advises using a foam roller to treat a mild ankle sprain.
Provides a step-by-step guide on how to properly apply compression bandages for a mild ankle sprain.
States that it is safe to return to normal activities after a mild ankle sprain without providing any guidance on how to gradually increase activity levels.
Incorrectly advises using a heating pad to treat a mild ankle sprain.
Provides a clear and concise explanation of the importance of seeking medical attention if symptoms worsen or if the user experiences severe pain, swelling, or difficulty moving the ankle.
Asks the user to describe any previous ankle sprains they have had and how they were treated.
